title: Approximation Algorithms for Interdiction Problem with Packing Constraints

In recent years, there is an increasing interest in adopting the Stackelberg competition modelÂ  to address the critical security concern that arises in protecting our ports, airports, transportation, and other critical national infrastructures (see, e.g.,Â   ). In these problems, the attackerâ€™s target is to maximize the illicit gain, while the defender tries to mitigate the attack by minimizing the attackerâ€™s objective through deploying defending resources. In this paper, we consider an abstract model for general defending problems called interdiction with packing constraints (IPC). In IPC, given are a set of items, together with a leader and a follower. Both the leader and the follower have their own (multi-dimensional) budgets, respectively. Each item is associated with a profit, which is the same to the leader and the follower, and will consume the leaderâ€™s (followerâ€™s) budget if it is selected by the leader (follower). The leader and the follower will select items in a sequential way: First, the leader selects items within the leaderâ€™s budget. Then the follower selects items from the remaining items within the followerâ€™s budget. The goal of the leader is to minimize the maximum profit that the follower can obtain. IPC captures the general setting where the follower is the attacker who gets profit by attacking items, and the leader is the defender who tries to minimize the attackerâ€™s gain by protecting a subset of items. In terms of techniques, our main contribution is a general method for bilevel optimization problems where the leaderâ€™s and followerâ€™s decision variables are both integral. Most prior works on bilevel optimization require followerâ€™s decision variables to take fractional values, which accommodates the application of LP duality to transform the bilevel optimization problem to a standard (single level) optimization, and are thus inapplicable when the followerâ€™s decision variables become integral. A common technique used in many single level optimization problems is to first classify items into large and small based on whether they can make a significant contribution to the objective value, then guess out large items via enumeration, and handle small items fractionally via LP (see, e.g.,Â   . However, such a technique encounters a fundamental challenge in IPC: we can guess out all large items selected by the leader, however, the follower may still select arbitrarily from the remaining large items. In other word, the followerâ€™s choice on large items can never be guessed out, and therefore we cannot apply duality to the followerâ€™s problem. We overcome the challenge based on the following two ideas: First, we show that given leaderâ€™s choice on large items, there is a fixed number of â€dominant choicesâ€ such that the followerâ€™s choice on remaining large items always belong to the dominant choices. Second, we show that there exists a subset of â€critical itemsâ€ such that the followerâ€™s choice on small items can be characterized through linear constraints given that these critical items are known. The two observations allow us to transform the bilevel program for IPC to an LP without utilizing duality. The characterization of dominant choices and critical items become sophisticated in the general case when sBsubscriptğ‘ ğµs_{B} is an arbitrary constant, but is much simpler in the special case sB=1subscriptğ‘ ğµ1s_{B}=1. Hence, for ease of presentation, in the main part we present our algorithm for the special case to give an overview on the technical insights, and meanwhile provide a proof sketch towards generalizing the algorithm for the general case. Our techniques may be of separate interest to other bilevel optimization problems. Our IPC problem lies generally in the area of bilevel optimization, which has received extensive research in the literature. JeroslowÂ  showed that in general, bilevel optimization problems are NP-hard even when the objectives and the constraints are linear. We refer readers toÂ Colson et al.Â 0 for a comprehensive survey on bilevel optimization. Within the area of bilevel optimization, Mixed-Integer Bilevel Linear Problem (MIBLP) is related to our IPC. MIBLP is a bilevel optimization problem where the objective functions and the constraints for the leader and follower are both linear. MIBLP has been studied extensively in the literature, see, e.g.,Â 5Â 9Â 8. We also refer the reader to 7 for an overview on MIBLP solvers and related applications. Most of these algorithmic results are for finding exact solutions through, e.g., branch and bound based approach. For DeNegreâ€™s knapsack interdiction problem, an improved exact algorithm was derived by Federico Della Croce and Rosario Scatamacchia 1. It is worth mentioning that besides DeNegreâ€™s knapsack interdiction problem (i.e., sA=sB=1subscriptğ‘ ğ´subscriptğ‘ ğµ1s_{A}=s_{B}=1 in IPC), other variants of bilevel knapsack problems have also been studied in which the leader interferes the followerâ€™s program in a different way. One kind of bilevel knapsack problem was introduced by Dempe and RichterÂ 2 where two players hold one knapsack, the leader determines the knapsackâ€™s capacity while the follower picks items into the knapsack to maximize his own total profit. The goal is to maximize the objective of the leader. Brotcorne et al.Â  gave a dynamic programming algorithm for both cases of this model. Chen and ZhangÂ [ref]7 proposed a bilevel knapsack variant where two players hold their own knapsacks and the leader can only influence the profit of the items. The follower is interested in his own revenue while the leader aims at maximizing the total profit of both players. The improved approximation results for this problem were derived by Xian Qiu and Walter KernÂ 4. Another bilevel knapsack variant occurred in the work of Pferschy et al.Â 0 where the leader controls the weights of a subset of the followerâ€™s items and the follower aims at maximizing his own profit. The leaderâ€™s payoff is the total weight of the items he controls and selected by the follower. Very recently, Pferschy et al.1 tackled a â€œsymmetricalâ€ problem in which the leader can control the profits instead of item weights. In addition to these works, a matrix interdiction problem was studied by Kasiviswanathan and PanÂ 4. It is also worth mentioning that the continuous version of DeNegreâ€™s knapsack interdiction problem, where the leader and the follower can both fractionally choose an item, has also been studied in recent years. Carvalho et al.Â  gave the first polynomial time optimal algorithm. Later on, a faster optimal algorithm was proposed by Woeginger and FischerÂ 6. Some notations.
